pullRequest.body:
We give an explicit characterization of the sets in a σ-algebra generated by a singleton.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

If there were a way to directly rewrite `∃ x : Set Prop, p x` as `p Ø ∨ p {True} ∨ p {False} ∨ p {True, False}`, the proof could be simplified a bit.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

`+ mk_singleton`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>



bors r+

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11191599704/job/31114678956)
bors r-
Canceled.

Thinking about it. If we really want to prove results about cardinalities of finite sigma-algebras, it'd be better to prove that the sigma-algebra generated by n elements has cardinality at most 2^(n + 1), instead of only having the case n = 1.

Let's merge this. It is simple and has waited for a review long enough.

I only have one question about a simp attribute, but apart from that I think we could merge.

Let's merge this. It is simple and has waited for a review long enough.

I only have one question about a simp attribute, but apart from that I think we could merge.
Please mention `generateFrom` in the name. Otherwise it looks like the lemma is about `MeasurableSet {a}`.
`measurableSet_generateFrom_singleton_iff`? That's quite the mouthful.
I updated the theorem name.

Why did you remove this `@[simp]`?
I am not saying you shouldn't remove it, but I'd like to have more details about the reasons.
This was causing problems with simp confluence, where lemmas on `Set.univ` wouldn't fire when written in this form. My proof breaks with the simp attribute active.

I don't think we want this lemma. Wherever you want to use it, you should be using `generateFrom_singleton` directly.

This is of the same kind as people on Zulip asking how to show that all elements of some subgroup are of a certain form, rather than using the induction principles.

I too wanted it originally, and then I proved `generateFrom_singleton` and my problem was solved.

If I correctly recall, my actual application for this lemma was showing that the cardinality of this set is 4, which appeared as a special case in a more general formula for the cardinality of the generated sigma algebra. An induction principle can't be directly used to prove that.
Can we see the application?
It's in a draft PR I have, I'll link it in an hour or two when I'm on my computer.
FYI this is making the file too long, but you need to merge master to see it

pullRequest.title: feat(MeasureTheory/MeasurableSpace/Basic): sigma-algebra generated by an element
